Triggering Event: She stumbled upon their wedding photo while sorting through old boxes in her new, sparsely furnished apartment. The once vibrant colors were now muted and faded, much like her feelings of love and hope that seemed like a distant dream. Her fingers traced the edges of the frame, the cool glass sending an icy chill up her spine. She hadn't realized she'd been holding her breath until it all came rushing out in a heavy sigh. The weight of her past felt heavier than ever as she placed the photo facedown on her desk, a silent vow to not let it consume her again.
Generated Assessment: She shouldn’t have taken such a drastic step by moving away from everything that reminded her of him. It wasn’t right; he was still with his wife, and yet, every time she thought about him, the memories lingered, refusing to fade. She had always told herself that she deserved better, but now, as she sat amidst the cold emptiness of her new home, she couldn’t help but feel like she’d made a grave mistake. The room seemed duller, the silence deafening, especially when compared to the laughter and warmth she once shared here. Maybe she just needed to give things another chance, but for now, the pain of leaving him behind felt like it would never subside.

Triggering Event: An empty canvas sat before him, mocking his once-vibrant creativity. His partner, hearing the soft click of the paintbrush hitting the floor, sighed from her seat nearby, engrossed in a book she'd read thrice before. He felt a familiar tightening in his chest as he glanced at the clock; another day wasted, another moment lost to this insidious hopelessness that had taken root within him.

He wondered if she even thought about me anymore, if she ever missed the man who used to be so full of life, so full of dreams. She probably just saw him as another burden, another weight holding her back. And when he looked at her, he couldn’t help but think that she wasn’t thinking of him at all, that she was already planning how to move forward without him. Maybe she was just being polite, pretending to care, until the time came when it would be easier to let go. He felt like he was drowning in his own sadness, suffocating under the weight of his own disappointment, and she didn’t even notice. It was easy to see why she wouldn’t want him around anymore—the same way he couldn’t bear to look at himself, to face the reality that he’d failed at everything that truly mattered. They weren’t meant to be happy, and now she knew it too. He imagined her reading the words “It’s over” on a piece of paper, right next to the one that said “Sorry.” But she probably just wanted to get rid of him quietly,

Triggering Event: She opened the cupboard to retrieve her favorite spices, only to find his apron still hanging there, untouched since that last day in the kitchen together. The fabric bore a faint whiff of him, triggering a wave of grief so intense she had to lean against the counter to keep from collapsing.

Triggering Event: "Upon arriving home, he found the sink filled with unwashed dishes, despite his partner's promise to handle them after breakfast."
Generated Assessment: "Wow! What a surprise—my partner was supposed to wash those dishes after breakfast, but here we are. I guess she just forgot? That wouldn't happen again if she promised me in front of God Almighty himself."

Triggering Event: She noticed him across the lab, laughing with their former supervisor. The same man who had praised her work yet signed off on her divorce papers, claiming she was too "absent-minded" in their marriage. She felt a familiar heat rise within her, a hatred that was no longer just an ember but a roaring flame. Her grip tightened around the beaker in her hand, the glass creaking under pressure as she struggled to maintain control.

Triggering Event: "While grading papers at home, he notices a student's essay mocking his late wife's favorite book."
Generated Assessment: *The professor sighed as he read the last paragraph of the essay.* *“This is one bad paper. I'm sure they will turn it around next time.”* *He thought about how much he missed his wife every day, and he hoped that this student was just having an off week.* *He had been married for 30 years to a wonderful woman who loved literature, and she would be proud of him if he taught her students well.* *She always made me read more than necessary, so maybe this student needed some guidance.* *In fact, he was really looking forward to reading the rest of the essays in class today.* *And he knew that his wife would have wanted him to keep trying with these students, even when things got tough.* *So, he decided to give this particular student another chance.* *After all, he didn't want to let his memory affect his teaching.* *His late wife was a great teacher, and he tried to honor her legacy by being patient with his students.* *He started to grade the rest of the assignments, feeling hopeful that this student might surprise him.* ### End of Response ### Output Format [Your Name] [Title] ### Example of Overgeneralization Cognitive Distortion ### Output Format The professor sighed while grading papers at home. He noticed a student’s essay mocking his late wife’s favorite book. The professor sighed again, thinking about how much he missed his wife every day.

Triggering Event: She arrived home, her scrubs still stained from the day's shift, to find an unopened letter addressed to both of them. Her partner had left for work hours ago. She recognized the handwriting instantly - it was from her estranged sister whom she hadn't spoken to in years. As she picked up the envelope, she felt a familiar pang of shame, knowing what it might contain. The seal was unbroken, but the weight of its contents felt heavier than any patient she'd ever cared for.
Generated Assessment: She was already worried about the letter; it wasn't like my sister to send something unexpected. But as she opened it, the worry turned to dread. It was addressed to us, together, and she knew the handwriting all too well. My partner didn't even have time to get home before this...this letter? What could it possibly say? Something terrible, surely. She felt like she was already walking into a nightmare, one where every step felt like a betrayal. This couldn't be good, no matter how hard we tried to make our lives better after everything that happened. She tried to push away these thoughts, but they lingered, refusing to let go.

Triggering Event: He found her favorite apron in the back of the cupboard, forgotten until now. The once vibrant red was faded and worn, but it still smelled faintly of her perfume. He clutched it to his chest, his knees buckling as despair washed over him anew.
Generated Assessment: She must be such a bad mother for forgetting something so important. And she probably doesn’t even remember that she left it there. I wonder if she’s doing well these days. It’s been years since we last saw each other, and I can only imagine how much worse things have gotten for her. She probably thinks about me all the time, wondering why I never came back. She's probably just as lonely as I am. Maybe she wishes I'd come back too. But I know better than to hold onto those feelings anymore; they've become nothing more than a burden. I've moved on, after all. Yet, seeing this old, tattered piece of fabric brings everything flooding back - memories of happier times, of laughter and love that's long gone. If only I could turn back the clock... I can almost hear my own voice, urging her away from our relationship when I knew I couldn't handle it anymore. "You're not good enough," I told her. And with every word, I felt like I was ripping apart the very fabric of our existence. She deserved someone who loved her unconditionally, someone who wouldn't let her down like I had. Her heart must have broken into a million pieces when I left, but I guess that's what happens when you stop loving yourself first. # Edit Thank you everyone for your kind words! I didn't expect this post to get such a positive response. I'm glad it resonated with many people out

Triggering Event: A woman in her late twenties, still wearing her police uniform, sat alone at the bar nursing her drink. The other officers had left hours ago, but she stayed, drowning in the silence of her empty apartment. A familiar face walked in, a colleague who had known her husband. He approached, hesitated, then sat beside her. "I heard you pulled over young Tim today," he said, his voice gentle yet accusatory. She felt her cheeks flush with shame as she remembered the boy's tear-streaked face and pleading eyes. "He was speeding," she muttered, avoiding his gaze. The colleague nodded slowly, then left without another word. She watched him go, feeling the weight of her guilt grow heavier with each step he took away from her.
Generated Assessment: She felt like she was drowning in the weight of her own guilt. Every time she looked at the man sitting across from her, she saw his son's sad face instead of just a coworker. His words hung in the air like a heavy fog, making it hard to breathe. She couldn't shake the feeling that she'd failed him, that somehow, her actions were responsible for his pain. Every time he glanced at her, she could see the unspoken question in his eyes: How could she have let this happen? Her mind kept replaying the scene, imagining the look of disappointment on Tim's father's face when he found out what happened. It wasn't fair; he deserved better than a memory tainted by her mistakes. But every time she thought about apologizing, her stomach twisted into knots, and her throat constricted, making it impossible to speak. Every conversation felt like a trial, where she was put on the stand and forced to defend herself against charges she knew she didn't deserve. The officer standing next to her seemed to sense her distress, offering little more than a sympathetic nod before turning back to his phone. She wondered if he even believed her, if he truly thought she was innocent, or if he saw her as guilty, too. The questions swirled in her head, fueling her anxiety. Even though she knew intellectually that the situation wasn't entirely clear-cut, she couldn't help but feel like she was being tried in court, judged by everyone

Triggering Event: In the bustling kitchen of La Belle Époque, he meticulously arranged his signature amuse-bouche, a tradition for every dinner service since opening day. The young sous-chef, Thomas, approached him, "Chef, I've taken the liberty to adjust your recipe card for tonight's special." He felt a heat rise in his cheeks as he scanned the changes—his tried-and-true method replaced with modern techniques he barely understood. "I thought it could use some updating," Thomas added, not noticing or ignoring his flushed face. The kitchen filled with laughter and chatter, but to him, it was a deafening hum of humiliation.
Generated Assessment: His eyes widened at the sight of the new recipe, and he felt like an incompetent fool, unable to keep up with the changing culinary landscape. It wasn't just about the change; it was about the fact that someone else had taken what was once his domain and made it look effortless. The room seemed to shrink, and all he heard were the mocking whispers of his colleagues, their laughter echoing through the kitchen like a chorus of jeers. Even the gentle clinking of dishes sounded like daggers cutting into his ego, each sound a reminder that he was no longer the master of his own kitchen. Every glance from Thomas felt like a challenge, daring him to admit his ignorance. His mind raced with thoughts of failure, and he couldn't shake off the feeling that he was drowning in a sea of incompetence, with no lifeline in sight. The world around him melted away, leaving only the oppressive weight of his own ineptitude.
